title: MIT Emergency Information
text:
Thursday, February 9th, 2017 Thursday, February 9, 2017 9:45 PM MIT will reopen at 7 a.m. on Friday, February 10, but it is anticipated that commute times tomorrow may be longer than normal. Given these circumstances, the Institute asks faculty and supervisors for flexibility, as employees and students may arrive later than usual. For hourly paid staff, the Excused Lateness Policy will be in effect on Friday (Personnel Policy Manual Section 5.7.2 ). Thursday, February 9, 2017 3:50 PM 
The emergency closing has been extended through tonight. Non-essential night shift employees are not expected to come to work. We expect that the Institute will re-open at 7 a.m. on Friday, February 10. 
Any further changes will be announced on this page, on the MIT homepage , and on the Snow Line (617-253-7669 or 617-253-SNOW). Thursday, February 9, 2017 12:40 AM 
Due to the snowstorm, MIT will be closed for all non-essential personnel on Thursday, February 9, beginning at 7 a.m. Classes will also be canceled. We expect that the Institute will re-open at 11 p.m. on Thursday, February 9. 
Any further changes will be announced on this page, on the MIT homepage , and on the Snow Line (617-253-7669 or 617-253-SNOW). Wednesday, February 8, 2017 6:15 PM 
A significant snowstorm is forecast for the Boston area on Thursday, February 9. As of now, MIT expects to be open. As we continue to learn more about the path of this storm, we may have additional information. If the decision changes, an announcement about closing will be made on this page, on the MIT homepage, and on the Snow Line (617-253-7669 or 617-253-SNOW). 
We encourage employees to discuss with their supervisors whether they can effectively work from home on Thursday, and we encourage supervisors to grant those requests where possible. Essential personnel, of course, must report to work. Other employees who cannot work from home, but who cannot get to work due to the storm, may use any accrued vacation time or personal time. 
If MIT will be open as usual, we encourage everyone who can to leave their cars at MBTA or commuter rail stations and take public transportation. If the commute is slow, MIT will follow its policy of Excused Lateness by Institute Notice for tomorrow ( Personnel Policy Manual section 5.7.2 ). Under that policy, employees who are late in reporting to work because of the snow will be paid for the hours they were normally scheduled to work, and no disciplinary action will be taken for tardiness. No special code is used, and the hours of excused lateness are simply recorded as hours worked. MIT is committed to the safety and security of every member of the MIT community. In the event of a campus emergency, news and information will be posted to this site and to the MIT home page . We strongly encourage you to sign up for the MIT Alert , text messaging service, part of the Institute's comprehensive emergency notification system, to receive an SMS message on your cell phone in the event of life safety or public health emergencies. To report an emergency, call MIT Police at 100 from a campus phone, or 617-253-1212 from an off-campus or cell phone. Please bookmark this website as http://emergency.mit.net . The site address http://emergency.mit.net expands our options to run this website from locations other than MIT. MIT ALERT is the Instituteâs emergency notification program, designed to provide information and advisories via a number of communication channels including Institute voicemail, email, and text message, for the safety and security of the MIT community. In the event of an emergency, MIT Alert advisories will be posted to some or all of these channels: MIT's home page MIT's emergency phone line 617-253-SNOW (3-7669) MIT email Personal cell phones and mobile devices (MIT Alert text messages) MIT Cable TV (emergency broadcasting system) MIT Radio (WMBR)
